content.webTitle: England’s Roy Hodgson affirms belief in team but neutral on Euro question

fields.headline: England’s Roy Hodgson affirms belief in team but neutral on Euro question
fields.bodyText: As Roy Hodgson pulled up a seat alongside James Milner, England’s stand-in captain, at the team hotel and got down to discussing the important subjects – the kit, he said, had nothing to do with him – one of those in his company threw in the question that invariably crops up before a tournament. England have just beaten Germany, the team who put seven past Brazil en route to winning the last World Cup, and the hype-meter has been duly cranked up on the back of the finest performance of the Hodgson era, as it often tends to be when there is a major tournament approaching. So, does Hodgson think England, with all those disappointments behind them, 50 years of hurt and all that, can actually surprise everyone and go to France in the summer as genuine contenders to win the damn thing? Thankfully, the England manager chose the sensible option. “It’s the impossible question, isn’t it?” he said. “If I say yes, then it’s ‘Hodgson thinks we can win the Euros!’ headlines. If I say that it’s going to be tough, and too much to ask of this young team, then it’s ‘Hodgson has no confidence in the team’. “All I can say is that these players haven’t done it yet in a tournament. We still don’t really know if this young group is going to perform in tournament conditions against much more experienced teams such as Germany, who are used to reaching finals and winning tournaments, or France, the home nation. “So the question remains an impossible one to answer. I can only be boring and cliched and say I believe in this team, absolutely. I believe we’re going to be ready and I believe the players will go into games believing they can win them and believing they can do well. But for me to say ‘this is what we’re going to do’ would be very foolhardy in the first place and, secondly, dishonest because the truth is I don’t know.” He couched it perfectly, especially for those who were with him on the training camp in Miami before the World Cup when, barely a day after one of his predecessors, Sven-Goran Eriksson, stated there was “absolutely no way” England could win it, the manager abandoned all restraint and fell into the trap. England, Hodgson said back then, could become the first European nation to win the tournament in South America and “anyone who thinks we can’t is barking up the wrong tree”. That did not go too well and everyone thankfully in the England camp appears to be more circumspect these days, even if Jonjo Shelvey did let slip when he was called up last August that Hodgson had told his players there was no reason why they could not go to France with the ambition of beating everyone else. For now, however, the most important matter against Holland on Tuesday night is for England to continue their forward momentum and, unfortunately for Jack Butland, the goalkeeper’s fractured ankle has been a reminder of the harsh facts of football life before these tournaments. Hodgson was deprived of an entire XI of injured players before Euro 2012 and the reality is that Butland will probably not be the only absentee to suffer this misfortune. For Butland, facing a three‑month lay-off, there is no chance. “Is it too strong to say your heart’s been broken?” Hodgson asked. “His dream has certainly been shattered for another couple of years. It’s a devastating blow.” Hodgson went on to talk about the “element of risk” that would be attached to selecting Daniel Sturridge and Danny Welbeck in the summer, a statement that is borne out by the amount of football the two forwards have missed since the 2014 World Cup. Sturridge, in particular, needs an injury-free run given that this will be his first start for England since September 2014. Hodgson regards him as the most naturally talented of all his forwards but it is a reflection of Sturridge’s stop-start career that, 27 later this year, the Liverpool striker has not even started 100 Premier League games. A lot of players – Wayne Rooney, for one – can be slow to find their best form after injuries but, in Sturridge’s favour, at least that does not seem to be one of his issues. “When you’ve been out for such a long time the question normally is how quickly a player takes to get back up to speed,” Milner, his team-mate at Liverpool, said. “It might take weeks, it might take months. For him it seems to take a warm-up. Then he’s straight out there, chopping left to right, beating players, his touch is there, his ability in front of goal. I’ve seen absolutely no change in him at all.” Otherwise the match presents a chance for Danny Drinkwater to try to stand out in the way that Dele Alli and Eric Dier did in Berlin. Drinkwater will make his debut in a vastly changed lineup and the only minor disappointment for the Leicester City player, perhaps, is that it will be in one of the new England kits that has prompted so much criticism. Gary Lineker described the away version as the worst England strip in history during the Germany game and it was intriguing to learn from Hodgson that the players had been consulted about the design – but that nobody had asked the manager. Hodgson, one imagines, would rather a traditional all-white look for Wembley and the Football Association’s most high‑profile employee sounded suspiciously as if he had been briefed what to say when it was put to him that England’s designers had suffered a wardrobe malfunction. “As far as kits are concerned, the only thing that interests me is the person wearing the shirt,” Hodgson said. “As long as I’m happy with the players wearing the shirts, I’m not prepared to enter into a debate on the colours. But I’m happy to let everyone out there have an opinion.”
